statement: This is a solid study that directly adapted a previously well-established money-pain trade-off task and analytical pipeline to assess hyperaltruistic preference in separate decision contexts.
Context-dependent decisions have gained more and more attention in literature in recent years, hence this study is timely.
The oxytocin study is done with great methodological rigor.
Both studies will include proper power analysis to determine the sample size.

The definition of 'hyperaltruistic' is unclear - it seems to mean 'willing to pay more to reduce other's pain than their own pain', but participants never actually PAY something to reduce the other's pain in the proposed task, and it's unclear what makes it 'HYPER-altruistic' rather than simply 'altruistic'.
The research plan mentions that 'boundary conditions' remain unexplored in the introduction, but this idea is never developed further - what boundary conditions mean in this task context is unclear.

The motivation for examining decision context is not well justified - it comes somewhat out of the blue that the research plan states investigating decision context without explaining why this factor is more important than studying other potential factors.

The research plan includes two types of models (harm aversion model and logistic regression models) that look similar, and it's unclear if there is a way to combine them rather than using both separately.
The research question examining the boundary conditions of hyperaltruistic tendency in moral decision-making and its neural basis is theoretically important.
Manipulating the brain via pharmacological means (oxytocin administration) offers a causal understanding of the neurobiological basis of the psychological phenomenon in question.
Individual difference analysis using personality questionnaires reveals interesting moderators of the behavioral tendency.
The theoretical hypothesis needs to be better justified, as there are studies addressing the neurobiological mechanism of hyperaltruistic tendency which are not adequately addressed.
Some of the planned exploratory analysis seems underpowered, such as large multiple regression models with only about 40 participants in Study 2.
There is inaccurate conceptualization of utilitarian psychology and the questionnaire (Oxford Utilitarianism Scale) used to measure it.
The pain component of the paradigm is well designed, as is the decision-making task, and overall the planned analyses are well suited to evaluating and interpreting the data.
The research plan does not provide evidence to support why any of the behavior being measured is extreme enough to warrant the modifier 'hyper' in hyperaltruism.

The task does not constitute altruism, but rather the decision to engage, or not engage, in instrumental aggression - deciding to hurt someone for personal benefit (whether acquiring financial gain or avoiding loss) is the definition of instrumental aggression, not altruism.

In the proposed studies, there is no possibility of acting to benefit the other participant in any condition - true altruism would be to accept shocks to the self for the other's benefit, but altruism is not equivalent to refraining from engaging in instrumental aggression.

The interpretation of this task as assessing instrumental aggression is supported by the focus on the Instrumental Harm subscale of the Oxford Utilitarianism Scale rather than the Impartial Benevolence subscale.

The research plan should better incorporate evidence from non-human animals on origins of oxytocin as a hormone selected for its role in maternal care and defense, as the non-human animal literature regarding oxytocin effects is more robust and definitive than the human literature.
It will be important to explain why oxytocin would be relevant to refraining from instrumental aggression by drawing on the non-human animal literature showing that oxytocin motivates defensive care.
